physical_appearance:This is a booklet. It features an image that is printed against a sheet of paper that has blue and red lines. The image shows stars and musical note symbols shooting from a stylised volcano. The title is printed in large Chinese text on the top right
 with the subtitle printed along the bottom. the date is printed at the bottom-right. The booklet is quite stained
 and folded around the edges.

sgcool_label_text:This pouch containing booklets
 notes and a badge belongs to part of a collection of artefacts owned by Chan Phui Kong who was involved in the World War II underground resistance movement known as Force 136. Chan’s collection forms part of a larger collection of materials gathered by Tan Chong Tee (1916- 2012)
 who was also a key member of this resistance group. The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee
 which date from the late 1980s to early 2000s. \r\n\r\nForce 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.\r\n\r\nThe notes contain information on the nature of explosives and how to proceed with a guerrilla mission.

metadata.sgcool_label_text:
This pouch containing booklets, notes and a badge belongs to part of a collection of artefacts owned by Chan Phui Kong who was involved in the World War II underground resistance movement known as Force 136. Chan’s collection forms part of a larger collection of materials gathered by Tan Chong Tee (1916- 2012), who was also a key member of this resistance group. The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee, which date from the late 1980s to early 2000s. 

Force 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.

The notes contain information on the nature of explosives and how to proceed with a guerrilla mission.
